blocks.html: CALL FOR EVIDENCE
FOR AN INITIATIVE (without an impact assessment)
This document aims to inform the public and stakeholders about the Commission's work, so they can provide feedback and participate effectively in consultation activities.
We ask these groups to provide views on the Commission's understanding of the problem and possible solutions, and to give us any relevant information they may have.
Title of the initiative Programme for Agile and Rapid Defence Innovation (AGILE)
Lead DG – responsible unit Directorate-General for Defence Industry and Space (DG DEFIS), Unit A1 – Defence Policy and Innovation
Likely Type of initiative Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing the Programme for Agile and Rapid Defence Innovation (AGILE)
Indicative Timing Q1-2026 (in March as announced in the EU Defence Industry Transformation Roadmap)
Additional Information EU Defence Industry Transformation Roadmap
About the EU Defence Innovation Scheme (EUDIS)
A. Political context, problem definition and subsidiarity check
Political context

Europe is facing a sharply deteriorating security environment, marked by growing geopolitical instability, high-intensity warfare on its borders and increasing strategic competition. Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine has underscored the urgency of strengthening EU defence readiness and credible deterrence, while demonstrating how rapidly battlefield dynamics can evolve through the fast development and deployment of disruptive technologies.

Defence innovation cycles are accelerating at unprecedented speed. Emerging and disruptive technologies (such as AI, cyber and space) are increasingly critical for military operations. New defence players – start-ups and scale-ups, some coming from civilian and dual-use markets – are becoming an important driving force for the transformation of the EU defence industry, bringing faster iteration cycles, greater flexibility, cost-efficient solutions and novel operational approaches.

Supporting defence innovation is a strategic priority at EU level. The Preserving Peace – Readiness Roadmap 2030 and the White Paper for the Future of European Defence – Readiness 2030 stress the need to accelerate innovation, shorten the time to market and ensure the rapid uptake of disruptive technologies to support EU defence readiness. Building on this strategic direction, the EU Defence Industry Transformation Roadmap, adopted on 19 November 2025, calls for a fundamental shift in mindset and processes across the European defence ecosystem towards greater speed, agility and risk-taking. It explicitly identifies the need to develop new, more responsive approaches to support disruptive defence innovation and the emergence of new defence players.

The EU has already launched several initiatives to support defence research, innovation and new entrants. The European Defence Fund (EDF) provides significant support for collaborative defence R&D, including disruptive technologies. As part of it, the EU Defence Innovation Scheme (EUDIS) provides targeted support to new defence players. In addition, the Hub for EU Defence Innovation (HEDI), launched by the European Defence Agency in 2022, acts as a platform fostering close collaboration among Member States and EU stakeholders on defence innovation matters. As far as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is concerned, the DIANA programme, the NATO Innovation Fund and the recently launched Rapid Adoption Action Plan also aim to accelerate the adoption of new defence technologies and support new defence players.
While these instruments play a key role in strengthening Europe's defence innovation base, the evolving security and

technological environment highlighted in the EU Defence Industry Transformation Roadmap points to the need for additional, faster and more flexible mechanisms capable of delivering high-impact defence innovation at the pace required by today's threats. Among other initiatives, it proposes a pilot instrument for rapid defence innovation (AGILE), which should test fresh ways of engaging with new defence entrants. The proposal for a regulation establishing this instrument is to be adopted in Q1- 2026 so that lessons can be drawn from its implementation ahead of the EU's next long-term budget for 2028-2035 (known as the multiannual financial framework or MFF).
Problem the initiative aims to tackle

The EU defence innovation framework is not yet fully equipped to respond to the rapidly changing nature of modern warfare. This was pointed out in the Interim Evaluation of the European Defence Fund (EDF) in 2025, as well as in extensive defence stakeholder consultations (including through the 2025 Strategic Dialogue with the European Defence Industry and the Implementation Dialogue to prepare the Defence Readiness Omnibus package.

Not all EU countries have instruments to support defence innovation. Moreover, those at EU level: (i) cannot be deployed with the necessary agility to face the challenges; (ii) are too slow in their implementation; (iii) are fragmented; and/or (iv) impose a high administrative burden on beneficiaries. The Defence Readiness Omnibus is set to simplify EDF procedures for disruptive technologies and SME calls. However, the inherent procedural requirements mean that it still takes at least 12 months for EDF grants to be awarded.
Key challenges identified for defence innovation support at EU and national level include the following.

• ·Administrative burden and lengthy funding timelines, which disproportionately affect start-ups, scale-ups, and SMEs developing deployment-ready solutions at high technology readiness levels (TRL). These lengthy timelines are not suited to fast innovation cycles and rapidly evolving operational requirements, causing promising defence innovations to struggle to move from development to deployment and hindering EU defence sector competitiveness.
  • ·Difficulties in securing co-financing: the EDF interim evaluation notes that the defence industry has difficulties in securing the required co-financing for development actions with Member States and Norway.
  • ·Limited support for smaller and innovative projects: there is a need for appropriate funding for complex and costly capabilities, while ensuring the right balance in supporting smaller and highly innovative projects.
  • ·Need to strengthen synergies with civilian technologies, particularly for strategic technological sectors.
Basis for EU action (legal basis and subsidiarity check)
Legal basis
The proposed regulation is based on Article 173 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (industrial policy).
Practical need for EU action

The initiative is necessary because coordinated EU-level action is crucial for swiftly achieving credible deterrence and technological leadership in defence. The rapid innovation cycles seen in modern warfare, as highlighted by the war in Ukraine, require the EU to be able to swiftly develop and deploy innovative defence solutions.

It meets the principle of subsidiarity because Member States' action alone cannot sufficiently address the challenges identified at the required scale and speed in line with EU strategic interests. Not all Member States have mechanisms to support rapid defence innovation, leaving innovative companies in some countries without access to funding opportunities. Even where national instruments exist, they typically have a domestic focus and lack the scale needed to support cross-border deployment of solutions meeting EU-wide operational needs. This results in fragmented efforts, duplicated investments, and missed opportunities for collaboration across the EU's Defence Technological and Industrial Base (EDTIB).

An EU-level action like AGILE provides clear added value by ensuring all companies across Member States have equal access to fast, streamlined funding regardless of national policy in their home country. By operating at EU scale with simplified procedures and short award times, AGILE can respond to the pace of modern warfare more effectively than fragmented national approaches. It tackles cross-border challenges by supporting solutions that meet EU Member States' operational requirements, tapping into the innovative potential of the EU industrial ecosystem as a whole and enabling new defence players to emerge across the EU. This coordinated approach reduces duplication, maximises the impact of EU investments, and
decreases collective reliance on non-EU systems in ways that individual Member States' actions cannot achieve.
B. What does the initiative aim to achieve and how
In line with the problems identified, the Regulation establishing AGILE will have three key objectives.

• 1.Mission-driven R&D support: AGILE will provide rapid and flexible support for defence innovation that responds to urgent defence and security needs identified by Member States and associated countries, delivering results within a short timeframe (four months to award). Implementation will be based on streamlined procedures and governance, with simplified application and evaluation processes to reduce the administrative burden.
  • 2.Enhancing cross-border collaboration and deployment: AGILE will support the cross-border uptake of innovative defence capabilities, facilitating collaboration between Member States and promoting the uptake of new technologies and solutions in the armed forces.
  • 3.Emergence and growth of new defence players: AGILE will strengthen the EDTIB and foster the emergence and growth of new defence players by providing dedicated support to single entities, particularly SMEs, start-ups, and in some cases small mid-cap companies. It will focus on rapid delivery of highly innovative, cost-efficient, high TRL solutions, promoting a culture of innovation and risk-taking in the defence sector.

AGILE will fully complement the EDF, which focuses on long-term, collaborative R&D for complex, costly systems. In line with this urgency logic, it will provide support to single entities, particularly SMEs, including start-ups, and in some cases small midcap companies. It will have a strong emphasis on leveraging and adapting civilian technologies for defence purposes, enabling dual-use innovation and enhancing synergies between defence and civilian research and innovation ecosystems. This approach will allow the defence sector to benefit from cutting-edge developments in areas such as AI, robotics, advanced materials and cybersecurity.
Likely impacts
AGILE is expected to demonstrate new pathways for more efficient defence innovation support that could inform actions under the next MFF.

• ·It will test streamlined funding mechanisms for innovative start-ups, scale-ups and SMEs in the defence sector, demonstrating faster routes to market for defence innovation. It will boost defence readiness by delivering innovative defence solutions aligned with the needs of armed forces in the EU Member States and associated countries.
  • ·It will contribute to improved protection of people in the EU, by improving the technological edge of European armed forces and by strengthening deterrence.
  • ·It will demonstrate the feasibility of a lower administrative burden and accelerated procedures for supported companies (startups, scale-ups and SMEs) which are currently disproportionately affected by the lengthy timelines of existing defence R&D programmes, providing valuable lessons for future programmes.
The initiative will affect the following stakeholders.

• ·People in the EU, by supporting job creation in innovative defence companies and contributing to better military readiness.
  • ·EU Member States, Ukraine and Norway, by providing defence solutions to armed forces.
  • ·Industry, since AGILE will be focused on defence start-ups, scale-ups and SMEs, and will have short award times and a low administrative burden. AGILE will also contribute to facilitating access to contracts for defence start-ups, scale-ups and SMEs.
AGILE will be open to companies from EU Member States and associated countries.
The initiative is not expected to have any significant environmental consequences.
Future monitoring

The implementation of AGILE will be closely monitored throughout the process, with a focus on its ability to deliver rapid, highimpact defence innovation. Monitoring will track key aspects such as the speed of decision-making, award times, the participation of new defence players (including SMEs and start-ups), the involvement of Ukrainian bodies, and the transition from innovation to testing or deployment.
The Commission will monitor implementation to inform decisions on future EU defence innovation instruments and the design of programmes under the next MFF from 2028.
C. Better regulation
Impact assessment
On the basis of the Better Regulation rules, an impact assessment is not required for this initiative.

The initiative is expected to have a limited impact in the short term. It has a limited budget for one year, coming from internal reallocations within the current EU budget dedicated to the defence industry. The funds will essentially target the same type of beneficiaries (the defence industry, particularly SMEs and start-ups) as existing programmes, just through a more agile and responsive instrument. Moreover, the initiative is highly targeted in scope and time. It is expected to have a duration of one year (2027), within the current MFF (with a possible extension into early 2028), with the objective of drawing lessons for supporting defence innovation ahead of the next MFF. Therefore, conducting an impact assessment would be disproportionate.

Given the pilot nature of the instrument, the Commission will prepare an implementation report at the end of the implementation period to present the key achievements and lessons learned. This will inform decisions on future EU defence innovation instruments and the design of programmes under the next MFF from 2028.
Consultation strategy

Feedback on this call for evidence may be submitted in any of the 24 official EU languages in the four weeks following publication of the call for evidence on the Have your Say portal (public submission). A summary report will provide an overview of the contributions received.

The specific nature of defence innovation requires technical expertise and the handling of information that is not intended for the public. As a result, the proposed initiative will build on the extensive consultation process that has been carried out with stakeholders, including Member States, industry (both established defence players and new entrants) and think tanks, for the preparation of several initiatives by DG DEFIS, including the EU Defence Industry Transformation Roadmap.

This consultation process included: (i) the Strategic Dialogue with Industry on 12 May 2025; (ii) the Implementation Dialogue with the Defence Industry on the Defence Readiness Omnibus on 19 May 2025; (iii) the Roundtable with New Defence Players on 23 June 2025; (iv) the Roundtable with the Defence Industry on Drones on 28 November 2025; and (v) consultations/workshops with EUDIS Business Accelerator companies. It also builds on the feedback from stakeholders feeding into the EDF interim evaluation (2025).
